Simulation

Simulator class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Simulator(agents: List[Agent], envs: List[System], duration: float, dt: float, obj_fun=None, disturbances: List[DisturbanceSource] = [])[source]

A class for running a Sandbox simulation.

It is possible to write your own simulation loop, without too much difficulty, and sometimes you may find that the easiest way to customise. That being the case, this class mainly exists for convenience, for standardising, and to cut down on the amount of code in main scripts.

__init__(agents: List[Agent], envs: List[System], duration: float, dt: float, obj_fun=None, disturbances: List[DisturbanceSource] = [])[source]
Parameters:

  • agents (List[Agent]) – The list of agents to simulate.

  • envs (List[System]) – The list of systems which are not agents or disturbances to simulate.

  • duration (float) – The length of simulation time to run the simulation for.

  • dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate systems over.

  • obj_fun (function) – An objective function for evaluating the performance of some aspect of the simulation. Not used in the current implementation - it has been temporarily removed from all methods, and will either be introduced later or completely removed.

  • disturbances (List[DisturbanceSource]) – The list of disturbances to simulate.

get_data()[source]

A method for getting a Simulator’s data. This will include timestamps, as well as the data of all simulated systems, except for that of the DisturbanceSource s (this may be added in a later implementation).

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • list of data from all simulated agents: data["agents"]

  • list of data from all simulated environmental features: data["envs"]

  • list of timestamps from all simulation steps: data["ts"]

get_systems() → List[System][source]

Get the list of systems in the simulation. This is here for convenience, e.g. for an Animator to get the list of systems which it should draw.

perturb() → None[source]

A method for perturbing the various objects in a simulation. Only objects which have a perturb_fun implemented will be affected (see perturb in System).

reset() → None[source]

A method to reset a Simulator, so that it can be started again from the same initial conditions.

run() → None[source]

A method for running the simulation once, by calling step_forwards repeatedly until the simulation’s duration has been reached.

step_forwards() → None[source]

Step the simulation forwards in time, by stepping all of its systems, using the simulations dt parameter.

Animator class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Animator(systems: List[System] = None, screen_width: int = 700, paused: bool = False, delay: int = 0)[source]

A class for animating a simulation using PyGame. To simplify scaling, the display is square, i.e. has equal width and height. Whenever a system moves beyond any edge of the currently displayed area, the view will zoom out accordingly, by the same amount in both axes. The view will not zoom in again if the system moves back towards the centre.

__init__(systems: List[System] = None, screen_width: int = 700, paused: bool = False, delay: int = 0)[source]
Parameters:

  • systems (List[System]) – A list of systems to draw on the PyGame display.

  • screen_width (int) – The PyGame display height and width, in pixels.

  • paused (bool) – A flag, set by keyboard inputs in the animation, to specify whether or not the animation, and underlying simulation, should be paused. It is the job of the simulation to actually implement that pause, e.g. see the run_once method of SimulationRunner

  • delay (int) – The number of 10s of milliseconds to delay the animation by inbetween each pair of successive simulation steps. Can be used to slow an animation/simulation down in order to see what is happening more clearly.

draw_frame(t: float)[source]

A method for drawing a frame of of the animation.

Parameters:

t (float) – The simulation time variable, which will be displayed in the title bar of the PyGame display window.

shutdown()[source]

Stop the animation and close the PyGame window.

stop()[source]

Stop the animation.

write_title(t: float)[source]

A method for writing simuation info to the title bar of the PyGame display window.

Parameters:

t (float) – The time to be displayed.

SimulationRunner class

class Sandbox_V1_4.SimulationRunner(sim: Simulator, animate: bool = False, screen_width: int = 700, pause_ani=False, animation_delay: int = 0, perturb: bool = True, show_prog_bar=False)[source]

A class for running a batch of simulations, which may or may not be animated, as required.

__init__(self, sim: Simulator, animate: bool = False, screen_width: int = 700, pause_ani=False, animation_delay: int = 0, perturb: bool = True, show_prog_bar=False)[source]
Parameters:

  • sim (Simulator) – The Simulator which will be used (note: future implementations will not need this to be passed in, as it can easily be constructed here).

  • animate (bool) – A flag which determines whether or not the simulation runs will be animated. Note: if this is set to False, then no Animator will be constructed, so it cannot be changed during simulation runs. When this flag is set to True, the Animator is constructed, and you can the choose to use it, or skip it, using its controls.

  • screen_width (int) – The PyGame display height and width, in pixels.

  • pause_ani (bool) – If this flag is set to True (which is it by default), and simulation runs are being animated, then animations will always begin in the paused state.

  • animation_delay (int) – The number of 10s of milliseconds to delay the animation by, when one is used, inbetween each pair of successive simulation steps. Can be used to slow an animation/simulation down in order to see what is happening more clearly.

  • perturb (bool) – If this flag is set to True, then the objects in the simulation will be perturbed at the beginning of every simulation (if they implement a perturb_fun method).

  • show_prog_bar (bool) – A flag to deterimine whether a tqdm progress bar is shown for each simulation.

run_once()[source]

A method to run, and animate, a single simulation run.

Returns:

Data from the simulation run, as returned from Sandbox.Simulator.get_data()

Return type:

dict

run_sims(n: int = 1)[source]
Parameters:

n (int) – The number of simulation runs to execute.

Returns:

The data from all simulation runs, in a list of data dicts, as returned from Sandbox.Simulator.get_data()

Return type:

list[dict]
